note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT. The patient presents today for an acne follow-up at the last visit on 03/3/2021. She was prescribed following clindamycin lotion and tretinoin cream 4 to 5 % benzoyl peroxide wash for face and 5 to 10% for chest and back. This morning, the patient washed her face with the 4-5% and put the Tennoin cream for nighttime. She denies any redness, peeling, dryness with use of these medications. She does however note that she has not put much effort into the current treatment. She is happy with how things are going. Her acne on the face is improving. She also notes that she uses an acupuncture mask for her acne. This is one of the fun parts of her care. She asks the doctor to write down the pharmacy contact information for her at this point. She needs to see the patient once a year for her medicine. The pharmacy contact details are available on the patient's checkout sheet. She sends the patient home with samples of Panoxil 10% and coupons for the drug.
PHYSICAL EXAM
• Constitutional: in no apparent distress.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. 2+ pitting edema of the upper back and posterior shoulders. 3+ erythema of the bilateral lower extremities. 4+ ecchymosis of the facial area. Effort is not needed at this time. 5+ antioxidant therapy is indicated. 6. Examination of the back reveals scattered inflammatory pustules across the upper and lower planes. 7+  Breast tenderness and tenderness along the radial planes.
objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.shower routine: benzoyl peroxide wash for face and 5 to 10% for chest and back. Combination of antibiotic and sunscreen moisture is used. Tretinoin cream is used as recommended. Papules and pustules across the upper back and posterior shoulders are reduced. There are less than five inflammatory papules on the forehead cheeks and chin. There is a mild back initiation of vulgaris. The skin is well controlled in the face. The physical exam reveals scattered inflammatory pustulations. If necessary, topical steroid cream and tennoin cream are used. 
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN OF ACTION acne follow-up template for patient. He was prescribed following clindamycin lotion tretinoin cream 4 to 5 % benzoyl peroxide wash for face and 5 to 10 % for chest and back. I recommended continuing with the current treatment plan. Papules and pustules across the upper back and posterior shoulders there are less than 5 inflammatory acne papules. Tennoin cream was prescribed for nighttime and the sunscreen moisture stuff again. I advised him to use a higher strength tennoin wash. I also recommended continuing to use the acne mask daily to avoid flare acne. We reviewed the risks and benefits of acne medications today. I am going to send in a new refill for the clindycin with 11 refills, and the tretinin cream with 3 refills. The patient will follow up with me once a year for her medicine refill. I will also send her home with a dose of Panoxil 10 mg. She should use it every 6 to 8 hours as needed. If she runs out, we can consider switching to Tylenol or Motrin. I printed out the prescription print out with steps and coupons for the patient.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow up.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Maria Martin is a 76-year-old female who presents for follow-up. The patient was last seen here on 03/05/1946 and is here today for the same reason as before. She denies any headaches, dizziness, or nausea. She reports that she has been doing pretty good. Her sugars are not very well controlled. She is still taking her glimepiride 2 mg twice a day. The last time the patient was seen, her a1c was 9.9, and the doctor wanted her to increase it to 4 mg twice daily. She states that she is trying to eat healthier but she does not like pasta and wheat bread very much. She usually has 2 slices of bread in the morning and peanut butter sandwiches once in a while. She does not drink much water but she prefers to drink club soda. She smokes but is not ready to quit. She has a history of high cholesterol and vascular disease in her legs. She also has pain in her hips and upper legs. Her blood pressure was 116/74 mmHg a couple of weeks ago. She notes that her feet feel like hell.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: in no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy.
1• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
2• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
3• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the bilateral lower extremities, especially the right lower extremity. Lower extremity pain is mostly confined to the paraspinal area. Right upper quadrant is mild to moderate tenderness.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####. The current hemoglobin A1c is 9.9. The doctor wants to increase the Glimepiride to 4 mg twice a day. He wants to review the review of the systems. The patient is not having any headaches or dizziness. He is tolerating the high cholesterol and vascular disease in his legs. He's on the combination of medications: metoprolol 50 mg once a day, lisinopril 20 mg with hydrochlorothiazide 20 with 25 mg, amlodipine 10 mg, and atorvastatin 20 mg. He also has the high blood pressure, which is elevated at 116 on the top. He doesn't drink any alcohol or sodas. He used to see an optometrist, Dr. Sanchez, who wrote his prescription perfect.
ASSESSMENT AND PLANMaria Martin is a 69-year-old female who presents today for a follow-up of her diabetes, high cholesterol, vascular disease, and hypertension. Her blood pressure was 116/80 mm Hg at the time of her last visit. Her glucose levels are still elevated. She should increase her Glimepiride from 2 mg to 4 mg twice a day, but she is still taking 2 mg at this time. The new prescription is for 4 mg once a day. The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to review her symptoms. We will also review her current medications. She is currently on metoprolol 50 mg once day, lisinopril 20 mg, hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg, amlodipine 10 mg, and atorvastatin 50 mg. She also has pain in her hip and legs due to peripheral neuropathy. She does not like pasta, bread, or peanut butter sandwiches, so we will try to cut down on the number of slices of bread we eat per day. She smokes, but is otherwise otherwise otherwise doing well. She prefers to drink non-whitewashed tap water instead of alcohol. She will contact her optometrist

dialogue: [doctor] michelle king , date of birth 1/5/1986 , mrn q227631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies . [patient] hello , are you mrs. king ? [doctor] i am . [patient] i'm dr. phillips , very nice to meet you . [doctor] you as well . [patient] how can i help you today ? [doctor] yeah . so i mean i , right now i take 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day . some days it is fine , but others are just really bad . what do you feel ? [patient] it feels like burning . [doctor] in your chest ? [patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat . [doctor] in your throat and chest , alright . any difficulty with swallowing ? feels like food or liquids kinda get stuck ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay . that's good . any abdominal pain ? [patient] no , not really . [doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ? [patient] no . [doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ? [patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years . [doctor] okay and how long have you been on the omeprazole ? [patient] on the way it is now i think about a year . [doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ? i mean i can tell it's helped because some days i'll be fine and then some days i eat something and it feels terrible . are there anything that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint like food choices or stress ? sure , probably stress and food choices sometimes . okay . what things bother you ? [patient] spicy foods so i try not to eat them too often but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it . we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that even sodas even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato based products or citrus products ? [doctor] yeah sometimes but i still eat them . okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing though . how has your weight been ? pretty stable ? [patient] i would say pretty stable although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past 2 months . i have been under a lot of work stress . [doctor] what do you do for work ? [patient] i'm a paralegal . [doctor] okay and any family history of gi issues ? [patient] my grandmother had esophageal cancer . [doctor] on your mom or dad's side ? [patient] mom's side and my mom had some issues like acid reflux and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach . [doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ? [patient] i think maybe when i was younger . [doctor] but not in the last 10 years ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ? [patient] at one point i was on omeprazole and ranitidine , it did help . [doctor] but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken . [patient] okay . have a seat here and let me listen to your heart and lungs and then we can talk about a plan for you . [doctor] okay . so normal physical exam per my new patient template except for a well-healed abdominal surgical scar is noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ? i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around 1 month old . gotcha , okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . [patient] and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole 40 mg twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ? [doctor] yes . and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated beverages , citrus , and tomato based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . [patient] so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd even though you're taking the ppi . [doctor] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods . [patient] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms . [doctor] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me . so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium . that's fine with me , i'm definitely open to trying whatever . perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 mg twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd or upper endoscopy to look for potential causes of the gerd . we sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth down your throat , through your stomach and end in the small intestines . [patient] we would look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything . [doctor] okay . can i schedule that today ? yeah , you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary stress and medication changes . how does all of that sound ? [patient] that sounds good . [doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the check out desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment . please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT NAME: Michelle KingAGE: 39-year-old female.HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Reports history of acid reflux, work stress, anxiety, seasonal allergies, and a family history of esophageal cancer. She is a paralegal. She has been referred by her primary care physician, Dr. Scott, who referred her here. The patient has had her history of anxiety and seasonal allergies noted. She denies any abdominal pain, vomiting, changes in bowel movements, constipation, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding. She states that she has been eating spicy foods and drinking a lot of caffeine and carbonated beverages for the past 2 months. Her weight has been stable but she has not had much of an appetite. Her family history is significant with her mother having an esophagectomy when she was a baby and her grandmother having an upper endoscopy of her esophagus.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Stable. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
Gastrointestinal: Right now he takes 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day. He's been on it for about a year. No changes in bowel movements. No constipation, diarrhea, rectal bleeding.
VITALS REVIEWED
• Palpation: Normal. No enlarged lymph nodes. No bruits. CVA tenderness in the chest, throat, or abdomen.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.7071070710.1. Previous medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies. Concerning acid reflux, he takes 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day. He's been on this medication for about a year. His grandmother had esophageal cancer and his mom used to take some medication that coats the lining of your stomach. He was a baby and had his intestines when he was a month old. He has never had an upper endoscopy in the last 10 years. He doesn't have any constipation or changes in bowel movements. He drinks carbonated beverages. He avoids spicy foods. He is a paralegal and has been under a lot of work stress for the past 2 months. 
ASSESSMENT AND PLANningMichelle King is a 29-year-old paralegal who presents for a new patient visit for acid reflux. She has been experiencing symptoms since she was 12 years old. Her primary care physician referred her to this practice. The patient is currently on 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day. We discussed treatment options today, including switching to a daily diet of low-glycemic foods, eliminating spicy foods, and limiting alcohol. We also discussed the possibility of performing an upper endoscopy to evaluate for esophageal cancer. I recommended that the patient follow up with me in 3 months to check on her progress. If her symptoms have not improved, we may need to consider a referral to a gastroenterology specialist. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT OF PRESENT ILLNESS 39-year-old female, female with history of quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury, presents today for follow-up regarding concerns related to fever, febrile, significant constipation, significant urinary tract infection, elevated white blood cell count of 23,000, antibiotic therapy, labile blood pressure, headache, and vomiting, and was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms. She denies urinary tract infections. She states she was constipated when she was in the emergency department and denies she had an infection. She believes her constipation was the cause of her blood pressure being so high and she hardly pooped while she was there. When she returned home, she had a massive poop and she felt much better.

°C, systolic ejection murmur, pitting edema, and edema of the bilateral lower extremities. Decreased heart rate, gallops, and respirations. Alert white blood cell count of 23,000. objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.
X-rays and reviewed urinalysis were obtained and reviewed in the emergency department. There were concerns about ongoing urinary tract infection. The patient was treated with i.v. antibiotic therapy. She was discharged on 7/2/2021. White cell count was elevated at 23,000, which is normal. No obvious signs of infection were noted. No osteoarthritis was noted. White count was the only thing that the doctors were concerned about. No evidence of automatic dysreflexia could be present. No clear signs of arthritis could be identified. No abnormal bone marrow was identified. 
ASSESSMENT AND PLANMichelle King is a 39-year-old female with history of quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury. She presents today to follow up regarding her symptoms. She was admitted to hospital on 6/29/2021 and was discharged on 7/2/2020. She presented today with an elevated white blood cell count of 23,000, fever, labile blood pressure, headache, nausea, and vomiting. There were concerns for an ongoing urinary tract infection, but she was treated with i.v. antibiotic therapy and was eventually discharged after clinical improvement. Her white cell count was slightly elevated, but not dangerously so. She is constipated, but this appears to be rectal related. We will order a colonoscopy and stool culture to rule out any urinary tract infections. I advised her to drink plenty of fluids and follow up with me in 2 weeks to see if her constipation has worsened. I also recommended we obtain a urine culture, as well as a hemoglobin A1c and hemoglobin B1c. We also discussed the importance of maintaining a healthy weight. I explained to the patient that her blood pressure was elevated due to anemia, which could be related to an infection

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Ashley James. She is a 14-year-old female who is previously healthy, now here for evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney. The patient reports she came home 1 day sick with symptoms of abdominal pain on her right side. She initially thought she had an appendix. She was seen by her primary care physician, who treated her for a stomach virus, gave her fluids and sent her back home. The next day she was twice as bad as the first day. She continued to throw up, so the patient was referred back to the urgent care unit, where she was seen for 4 days and treated for an antibiotic. She has improved slightly, but she still complains about a lot of pain in her stomach. She mentions burning when she eats, and she mentions she has been unable to sleep. She denies fever, chills, or weight loss. She states she has a history of kidney stones, but the symptoms were present at one point in the past 3 years prior to this event. Dr. Rodgers explains that the patient is doing well today. She will complete an exam of her heart and lungs and move from there. 
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
. Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
. Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
Neurological: Alert and oriented x3. Speech is clear and fluent. Heel toe walking is normal. Cranial nerves grossly intact without focal neurologic findings. Normal reflexes and reflexes. Straight leg raise without assistance. No pronator pronator edema. Bowel sounds are normal. No expiratory tenderness, cyanosis, or cyanosis.

We will discuss the current evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney in detail. [Dr. Rgers] is one of your kidney doctors. He is on vacation. His primary care physician is out of town. He will not be able to see his patient today. His office is also unavailable. The patient is a 14-year-old female. Her lymph nodes were swollen and they found some infection. Her creatinine was elevated. She complains about a lot of pain in her stomach. She has not had any more throwing up or anything since the first day. 
ASSESSMENT AND PLANningAshley James is a 14-year-old female who is previously healthy. She presents today for evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney. We discussed the diagnosis and treatment options today. I explained that her symptoms are consistent with an infection. She will follow up with her primary care physician the next day. I will complete an exam of her heart and lungs and then we will move from there. The plan is to treat her conservatively. We will send her home with antibiotics 4 days of which she will take 2 of them today. She should feel better in about a week.

[patient] no , i also wear the left sometimes , the right is just worse but the splint helps . both have really gotten worse over the last month and i broke them my right wrist was definitely in worse shape . i've also been having some mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident and they told me it was a contusion . [doctor] and where would you say the tingling and numbness is ? [patient] on this side , it goes from here and here up to about here on the other side , it's from here to here . [doctor] i see . so on the right side you're pointing from the middle and ring finger all the way up the forearm and on the left the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger and is there any pain or just tingling and numbness ? it's mainly just sore , sometimes they throb but overall they feel weaker too especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens more when they hurt , but when it goes away , the tingling is dull . [patient] and when do you feel these symptoms ? well , really i guess just more so at night and they come and go throughout the day . [doctor] okay and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ? [patient] like feeling something , no , not that i can really think of though in general they maybe less sensitive than they should be but i can still feel they also gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should . [doctor] and are you still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety ? [patient] yes , i'm still taking those . i had prediabetes too , but i got it under control by changing my diet . [doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , correct ? [patient] no . [doctor] ri thank you mr. cook okay first we'll go over your review of systems correct me if i'm wrong in any of this constitutional you have fatigue and weight gain gi you have excessive appetite and bloating eyes have floaters , cardiovascular shows shortness of breath and leg swelling , endocrine , you're always hungry , skin , you have some nailbed changes , dryness , and itching , musculoskeletal , you have gout and muscle pain , and the remainder of the review of systems is negative . [patient] yeah , that's all correct . [doctor] alright we are going to go ahead and do the neurologic examination . let's look at the right hand first . can you feel this ? [patient] yeah , but a little less on these two fingers . [doctor] sensation is normal except pinprick sensation diminished in the third and fourth fingers on the right and how about on the left ? [patient] yeah but these two are little less . [doctor] sensation is decreased in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left . okay , let's test your reflexes now . reflexes are 1+ and symmetric . 2+ knees , toes are downgoing bilaterally . alright , i'm going to tap on your right wrist . do you feel anything ? [patient] yeah , it feels like a zing of my wrist and something into my elbow too . [doctor] and how about the left side ? [patient] yeah , same on that side too . [doctor] tinel's sign positive at both wrists and both elbows . rest of exam is normal . alright so what i am seeing today is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or potentially this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . however , your symptom presentation suggests bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome as the nerves in your wrist are aggravated by your past trauma . this is causing the pain and tingling you were describing to me . okay . so how we make it better ? first , i want to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from . we will need to schedule you for a nerve test , which is called an emg test . they will measure the responsiveness of your nerves to truly pinpoint where you're having your issues . [patient] that sounds fine to me . [doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release surgery . you could also refer , we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment . [patient] sounds good document . [doctor] alright keep wearing your splints and i will see you after those studies . [patient] thank you .
note:
CHIEF COMPLAINTMr. Martinez is a 60-year-old right-handed male who presents today for evaluation of numbness and tingling in his right wrist and left elbow. He sustained a head injury in a car accident last December and required surgery. He has had numbness in both of his hands ever since then. He states that the numbness has increased after his wrists healed. He wears a splint on the right wrist, but he also wears the left one sometimes as the right is getting worse. His right wrist was definitely in worse shape when he broke it, and he describes what he feels like a zing of his wrist and something into his elbow. The numbness is mainly noticeable at night and throughout the day but he denies any loss of sensation in his hands or fingers. The patient states that he experiences dullness and soreness in his fingers when they hurt, but overall they feel weaker when he is using them. He notes that they also feel less sensitive than they should be. He is still taking the coreg for hypertension and lexapro for anxiety. He had prediabetes but got it under control by changing his diet. He denies thyroid issues. 
PHYSICAL EXAM
Neurological: Alert and oriented x3.2 bilaterally. Decreased sensation in the 3rd and 4th fingers. Normal sensation on the left. Reflexes are 1+ and symmetric. 2+ knees. Lower extremity strength is low. Gastrointestinal: Excess appetite and bloating. Musculoskeletal: Shortness of breath and leg swelling. Endocrine, you have some nailbed changes, dryness, and itching.
Motor neurone disease: Right wrist is in good shape. Tingling is dull. Sensation is decreased in the 4th and 5 fingers.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####. We are going to do the neurologic examination of the right hand and review the review of systems. There is normal bony alignment and reflexes, 1+ and symmetric. 2+ knees and 2+ toes are downgoing bilaterally. 0.5° Cuspid titer is normal. White blood cell count is within normal limits. No evidence of hypothyroidism. No osteoarthritis. No signs of thyroid disease. No changes in diaphragm or adrenal function. [Doctor] ri is going to tap on the right wrist to test the tingling. 
ASSESSMENT AND PLANningMr. Cook is a 60-year-old right-handed male who presents for evaluation of bilateral brachial tunnel syndrome. He had a car accident in December of last year. He is currently in a splint on his right wrist. His symptoms have worsened since the accident. We reviewed the patient's clinical history and radiographic findings today. He has been compliant with his medications, including Protonix for hypertension and Lexapro for anxiety. We also reviewed his review of systems, which includes fatigue and weight gain, endocrine, vascular disease, skin, and gout. He also had prediabetes, which he believes may be related to his car accident. I advised him to continue taking the coreg for hypertension. I also recommended we obtain a CT of the right wrist to evaluate for possible carpal tunnel syndrome, and he will follow up with me once the CT results are available.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT Shirley Taylor is a 60-year-old right-handed female new patient referred by dr. Jacob Ward for evaluation of bilateral hand numbness and tingling. Shirley reports she has had this numbness in both of her hands since last December when she broke her right wrist. She is still wearing a splint, however, the right wrist has not improved since that time. The numbness is mainly on the right side, extending from the middle finger all the way up to the forearm and left pinky and ring finger. There is no pain associated with the numbness. Shirley describes her symptoms mainly as sore, throbbing, and dull. When she is using her hands, the pain and numbness are worse. The patient reports she experiences any loss of sensation in her hands or fingers like like feeling they are less sensitive than they should be. Shirley states she has been taking some nerve pain medicine, which she feels is doing its job. Shirley has a history of chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and diabetes. She reports she got her diabetes under control by changing her diet. Shirley is allergic to sulfa, which causes her to break out in a rash. Shirley will look up the medication she was prescribed for nerve pain.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINTRight medial unicompartmental arthroplasty. Status 6 weeks postoperative. No pain. No numbness on the right side of the knee. Right knee bend is good. There is mild swelling along the surgical incision. The patient is still numb on the left side, but this will get smaller as the nerves that innervate the skin across the knee heal. She is still unable to go back to work yet because of going up and down steps with the position she has, however, she will be able to return to work where she can sit for the shift with breaks. She will write a note and bring it to the clinic in 6 weeks and we will discuss her job status then. She has been cleared for telemedicine visit. The visit will just be to check in and make sure things are progressing okay. 
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION of the right knee shows good gait with decreased velocity. Normal reflex time is returned at 6 weeks. Range of Motion is low. No lifting greater than 5 or 10 pounds and no standing or sitting longer than half an hour. Examination of the incision shows nice incision. The nerves that innervate the skin across the knee heal slowly. There is mild swelling. Pain to palpation to the medial aspect of the knee. Assessment of the surgical site shows no swelling. Negative antalgism. Negative valgus and erythema. Right knee focused surgical scar.

ASSESSMENT AND PLANStephanie Morales is a 44-year-old female who presents today 6 weeks status post Right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty. There is still some numbness on this side of the knee. The incision looks nice and the incisional area is well-located. The patient will continue to work on her strength, range of motion, and endurance as the nerves across the knee heal. She should avoid lifting more than 5 pounds and sitting longer than half an hour without assistance for the next 6 weeks. Her return to driving is determined by when she feels safe to be able to be driven. She will contact her employer to arrange a telemedicine visit to check in and make sure things are progressing. We will talk again in 6 weeks and discuss her job again at that time.
